GuildTags.Name: paths
GuildTags.Value:
Here are some useful default paths:
**Windows Saves**: `%UserProfile%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\tModLoader` (This is typically found in `C:\Documents\`)
**Linux Saves**: `~/.local/share/Terraria/tModLoader/` or `$XDG_DATA_HOME/Terraria/tModLoader/`
**Mac Saves**: `~/Library/Application support/Terraria/tModLoader/`

**Windows Install**: `C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\tModLoader`
**Linux Install**: `~/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/tModLoader` or `~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/tModLoader`
**Mac Install**: `Library/Application Support/Steam/steamapps/common/tModLoader/tModLoader.app/Contents/MacOS`

**Mod Path**: Your manually installed mods are stored in a subfolder of the **Saves** folder called `/Mods`. Workshop mods are stored in `C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\workshop\content\1281930`, but you shouldn't touch the folder and instead unsubscribe in steam.
**Logs Path**: The Logs are found in a subfolder of the **Install** folder called `/tModLoader-Logs`.

GuildTags.Name: offline13
GuildTags.Value:
If you are getting that the Mod Browser is offline, there are several things you can check:
1st: Does everyone have this problem? If so, just wait, don't ask, we're working to fix it.
2nd: Can you access http://javid.ddns.net/tModLoader/DirectModDownloadListing.php ? If so, you can download mods from there. Since it doesn't work in-game, you might have a firewall issue. Check that Terraria.exe isn't blocked by your firewall. (use Google if you don't know how.) If you are using a VPN, that might also be blocking it, try disabling it or changing settings.
3rd: If you can't access that site, but it works for other people, you have a Government/ISP/Router issue. Basically the Mod Browser server is blocked by one of those. Nothing we can do about it. Use the Terraria forum or <#284077567986761730> to find mods to download and place them in `%UserProfile%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\ModLoader\Mods` (This is typically found in `C:\Documents\`) (or type `.paths` in <#242228770855976960> to find your mod path on other OS).

GuildTags.Name: bad
GuildTags.Value:
Calamity isn't the worst mod in the world but it certainly has a lot of issues. First up, most of the bosses are gimmicked Vanilla Inspirations, the biggest of which are Calamitas and Desert Scourge. Calamity also has a difficulty fetish, which means there's lots of difficulty settings. Half of them aren't even fair to vanilla gameplay, which brings up the fact that Calamity is balanced around itself, which means that any mod you add to it's side will either be dwarfed or get the gameplay so overpowered you'd think you're playing the Minecraft Orespawn mod. Don't forget the fact that the community is somewhat toxic, the mod is so big it's secluded from the browser instead of getting permission from Jopo to increase the upload size for the mod, and the overall mod is being meant for it's fanbase, not for anyone outside it...

Unless you want to call the mod good because it's fun. There's some good stuff in the mod like the Music and Sprites, but they're too good for even Terraria.

tl;dr = Balancing bad, Sprites and Music too good, people assume this mod is good because it's fun. I'd also say forge your own opinion before looking at mines.

GuildTags.Name: githubblocked
GuildTags.Value: If github is blocked in your country, you'll notice that the mod browser alternative website (<http://javid.ddns.net/tModLoader/DirectModDownloadListing.php>) also doesn't work. You'll need to trick it into giving you non-github download urls. Right click on a download link and `Copy Link Address`. Paste the url in the address bar and add `&m` to the end of it, then press enter. Example: `http://javid.ddns.net/tModLoader/download.php?Down=mods/RecipeBrowser.tmod&m`

GuildTags.Name: badsprite
GuildTags.Value:
Have you been **getting criticized?**
Have you wanted to **hurt** everyone that calls you bad?

Than you're fit to read this! Welcome to the badsprites tag, and **you**'ve been selected to read this. Here, you'll be schooled on what you did wrong!
------------------------------------------
Are you **deflecting?**

Yes, you are. You're calling other mods bad when you can't look at your own! You absolutely abhor the very idea that your spriting skills may be subpar! Maybe you even think you're better than the rest of the people there! The sprites are bad but you don't see it that way. You think you're high up in the ranks. Maybe even the KING where you come from. Boy are you in for a treat!
------------------------------------------
Does your sprite have **BANDING?**

If yes, you must be very new. Banding happens when you make two shades line up with eachother, creating a linear gradient which looks VERY ugly. If you're seeing this tag, you probably used this!
------------------------------------------
Is your color palette an **eyestrain?** 

It is, most likely! Your palettes are either too saturated or have too much value! Maybe they don't have any value! Your palettes absolutely SUCK! How to fix them? Hueshift. 

Now if you follow these, you might know what you did wrong! Become a better spriter and take some advice from other people so you hopefully don't ever see this tag next time.

GuildTags.Name: overlap
GuildTags.Value:
If you're wondering why you should avoid putting big content mods together, here's a little explanation on it.
The problem by doing so is that the content will overlap because the base purpose of big content mod, is to have content for every tiers of the game.
Meaning you'll end up with whole tiers of useless junk that are immediately useless, even more so if there is power creep in said mods.
It's a bit sad to lose all this content because it gets overshadowed, it doesn't do justice to the different mods used and becomes a big mess trying to figure out what is worth using.
So this is why it's preferable to use big content mods that are highly likely to be overlapping in different playthroughs so that you can fully enjoy them without wasting content away, and it'll reduce the junk you get.
Please respect yourself and the mods you use, and appreciate them to the fullest!

GuildTags.Name: vector
GuildTags.Value: Vector is fancy for line segment. It has a y-value and an x-value. Terraria’s y-axis is flipped (tiles with lower y-value are higher in the world), so bear this in mind. The x-value is width, y-value is height. Sometimes we use it to more accurately record a position in the world.

GuildTags.Name: dividetwo
GuildTags.Value: One really easy way to divide by two is “num >> 1”. However this only works properly with even numbers (31 >> 1 == 15). If a number is even, “num & 1 == 0”. These are much faster for a computer to do than “num / 2” and “num % 2 == 0”

GuildTags.Name: aistyle
GuildTags.Value:
How to find vanilla AI of a certain NPC or Projectile (short version, example is for NPC)
1. Find the number corresponding to the NPC here: `https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Vanilla-Content-IDs#npc-ids` (Example: QueenBee: 222)
2. Open up NPC.cs of your decompiled terraria, and search for `type == typeNumber` (Example: type == 222), and find the section of the code that declares width, height, damage etc, including aiStyle (Example: aiStyle = 43)
3. In NPC.cs, search for `aiStyle == aiNumber` (Example: aiStyle == 43)
4. Most of the time, there is only one result, which then leads to the code block responsible for the AI. You can check if you found the correct place if you have outlining enabled in Visual Studio, your found place should be in `VanillaAI()`
5. Sometimes, multiple NPCs use the same aiStyle, to exclude those NPCs you don't want the AI for, look for boolean expressions in that aiStyle code containing `type` and the `typeNumber` of your NPC of interest, or the others (!=, <=, >=, ==, be careful not to accidently delete code related to the type you try to clone)
For a more thorough explanation, and how to setup decompiled Terraria, visit `https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Advanced-Vanilla-Code-Adaption`

GuildTags.Value:
We need log files to help you. You'll find the log files in the logs folder. Look for `client.log`. (NOT the `.zip` file, the file named `client` or `client.log`) 
**Windows Logs**: `%UserProfile%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\ModLoader\Logs` (This is typically found in `C:\Documents\`)
**Linux Logs**: `~/.local/share/Terraria/ModLoader/Logs/` or `$XDG_DATA_HOME/Terraria/ModLoader/Logs/`
**Mac Logs**: `~/Library/Application support/Terraria/ModLoader/Logs/`
After you find the file, simply drag and drop it onto Discord.

GuildTags.Name: vanillasprites
GuildTags.Value:
If you are here trying to use this bot to get vanilla sprites from Terraria then read this:
1. Go to https://forums.terraria.org/index.php?threads/tconvert-extract-content-files-and-convert-them-back.61706/
2. Scroll down until you find a link that says TConvert-1.0.2.1.exe
3. Tap on the link and wait for the exe file to download.
4. Tap on 'Use Terraria' once you have opened TConvert-1.0.2.1.exe
5. Select an output folder (where you want the files to go)
6. Select what files you want extracted from Terraria. (Wave Bank are sounds)
7. Tap on 'Extract' and wait for it to complete (It takes around 10-15 minuites)
8. Open the output folder you selected earlier and find the sprite you are looking for
Hope this guide was useful.

GuildTags.Name: avoidgithub
GuildTags.Value: If you are having trouble downloading mods, and your client.log file says "Unable to resolve remote name: github...", you likely live in a country where Github is blocked, so we need to tell tModLoader to avoid Github. You can instruct tModLoader to avoid Github by doing the following: Close tModLoader, Open up "%userprofile%\Documents\My Games\Terraria\ModLoader\config.json", change `"AvoidGithub": false,` to `"AvoidGithub": true,`, save the file, then open up tModLoader again. If you are on Mac or Linux, the process is the same but the appropriate folder.

GuildTags.Name: commands
GuildTags.Value:
**Bot commands:**
`.mod [internalmodname]` - Returns information on a specific mod
`.mod >count` - Returns the amount of cached mods
`.ws [searchterm]` - Searches the Github wiki for a term
`.em [searchterm]` - Searches ExampleMod for a term
`.docs [classname] [methodname]` - Searches tModLoader API classes and Vanilla classes. Must be exact.
`.widget [modinternalname]` - Brings up an image of a specific mod's widget containing download information
`.msdn [searchterm]` - Searches Microsoft docs for a term
`.listmods [steam64id]` - Generates a link for the ranksbysteamid of the steamid64 provided
`.ping` - Returns the bots latency
`.tag` - Manages bot tags

GuildTags.Name: rotation
GuildTags.Value:
Terraria's rotation values are different than you'd expect.
For reference:
  directly left is **π** radians (**180** degrees)
  directly up is **-π/2** radians (**-90** degrees)
  directly right is **0** radians (**0** degrees)
  directly down is **π/2** radians (**90** degrees)
Rotation increases as you move clockwise along the circle, while it decreases as you move counter-clockwise along the circle.

**How to record your performance issues with dotTrace:**
**0.** Get dotTrace from <https://www.jetbrains.com/profiler/> (30 days trial is enough)
**1.** Load Terraria with all your mods and open your world.
**2.** Start dotTrace, click "Attach to Running App", click "Show All Processes", select "Terraria.exe", choose "Sampling" on the right panel, untick "Start Immediately", click "Run".
**3.** A small "Profilling Controller" window will appear. Click the 📌 button to make it appear on top of other windows if it doesn't do that already.
**4.** Switch back to your game. Press "Start" on the profilling controller.
**5.** Run around in your game and make it lag.
**6.** After half a minute or so, click "Get Snapshot and Wait" button on the profilling controller.
**7.** Performance Viewer window will open. Select it and press Ctrl+S. Choose a convenient location for the snapshot. Then find it in Explorer, upload it to some file sharing site (MEGA, Dropbox, Google Drive, FileDropper, etc) and post it.

GuildTags.Value:
(*Steam Instructions*) Follow these steps to get a fresh install of your game files:
**Terraria Instructions:**
1)  Delete the `Terraria` folder in `C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/steamapps/common`.  If you're on a non-Windows computer or have Steam installed elsewhere, type `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960> to get to the `tModLoader` folder, then just go back one folder to end up in the `common` folder mentioned earlier.
2)  Uninstall, then reinstall **Terraria** in Steam.

**tModLoader Instructions:**
1)  Delete the `tModLoader` folder in `C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/steamapps/common`.  If you're on a non-Windows computer or have Steam installed elsewhere, type `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960> to get to this folder.
2)  Uninstall, then reinstall **tModLoader** in Steam.

(Note:  your player and world saves are stored in a **completely separate** folder than the ones mentioned above.  If you delete any other folders, we are not responsible for you losing any of your saves.)

GuildTags.Name: avoidmydocuments
GuildTags.Value:
If you are having issues with the game failing to load because it can't create the Logs folder or a logs file, there are a few things to try. This issue can be identified by seeing errors mentioning FileNotFoundException pointing to a Logs folder or UnauthorizedAccessException. 

If you have BitDefender, you might need to allow Terraria.exe through the "Safe Files" feature. The same with Windows Defender or Avast.

If you can't figure that out, there is a way to tell tModLoader to save in another directory, bypassing the permissions issue. Follow the steps in this image guide: <https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/436261997416546305/668206693343035413/unknown.png>

You can also search ExampleMod in botworld by typing `.em [search term here]`. GuildTags.Name: badclassname
GuildTags.Value:
Hey there, looks like you got some errors with your class being named something generic like `Player` or `ModItem`.
Keep in mind that you should *never* name your classes the same as the ones that exist in the vanilla Terraria or tModLoader source code.
It will only confuse you and us when you get errors such as "no suitable method found to override".
If you are wondering if your class ends up doing this, ask us here or look through the Terraria source code yourself.  You can find how by typing `.adaption` into chat.

GuildTags.Name: objectnotdefined
GuildTags.Value: If you have this particular error while building mods after installing Visual Studio that claims that simple things like Object or List don't exist, but you know that you have all the correct using statements, you might have run into this strange bug. We don't know why this bug occurs, but basically the Reference Assemblies folder has somehow been corrupted. To fix this, delete `C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\Framework\.NETFramework\v4.5` and then in the Visual Studio installer, click More->Repair. This process will take quite a while, and you will need to restart your computer to complete the process.

GuildTags.Name: createmodpack
GuildTags.Value:
Here's the step-by-step process to creating your own modpacks in tModLoader:
1)  Enable the mods you want in the modpack
2)  Go to your **Mods** menu.  Click the `ModPacks` button
3)  Click the `Save Enabled as New Mod Pack` button
4)  A text prompt should appear.  This is where you name your modpack
5)  After submitting the name for your modpack, you should now see it in your **ModPacks** menu ingame.  The various buttons in the modpack's box should be self-explanatory
If you want to share your modpack with others, go to the `Documents/My Games/Terraria/ModLoader/Mods/ModPacks` folder and have them put the modpack's `.json` file there in *their* `Documents/My Games/Terraria/ModLoader/Mods/ModPacks` folder!

GuildTags.Name: badcsproj
GuildTags.Value:
Having issues with references in your project?  Or just having issues with your project in general?  Try doing the following:
1)  Move your mod folder out of `ModSources`
1a) If you don't know where this folder is located, the **Open Sources** button in the `Workshop > Develop Mods` menu can bring you to it.
2)  Make a new mod ingame with the same internal name as the one you had (the name of the mod's folder that you moved in step 1)
3)  Remove the code files except for the `.csproj` in the **new** mod folder
4)  Move everything from the old mod folder to the new one except for the `.csproj` and any Visual Studio files and folders (`.vs`, `bin` and `obj`)

GuildTags.Name: startserver
GuildTags.Value:
Read the following instructions if you want to start a modded server:
**IP Server**
1) Go into your install folder.  If you don't know where that is, do `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960>
2) Run `start-tModLoaderServer.bat`
2a) If you're running a 1.4 server, select `n` for Steam server
3) When prompted to port-forward, enter `y`
4) Select a world in the command prompt
5) Once the world has finished loading, the server host will join the IP `127.0.0.1` ingame
6) Everyone else will have to join the server host's **Public IPv4** address, which you can find by going to <https://whatismyip.com>

**Steam Server**
1) Go into your install folder.  If you don't know where that is, do `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960>
2) Run `start-tModLoaderServer-steam-friends.bat` (1.3 tModLoader) or `start-tModLoaderServer.bat` (1.4 tModLoader)
2a) If you're running a 1.4 server, select `y` for Steam server
3) Select a world in the command prompt
4) Once the world has finished loading, the server host will join the IP `127.0.0.1` ingame
5) Everyone else can join via Steam invites, though they **must** have the game already running before accepting the invite

GuildTags.Name: openproject
GuildTags.Value:
You will have a more difficult time modding if you don't use your mod's project in Visual Studio.
To open your mod's project file, follow these instructions:

***1.4 tModLoader Instructions:***
1) Close Visual Studio.
2) Go into your mod's folder in the `ModSources` folder.  If you don't know where the `ModSources` folder is, go into the **Develop Mods** menu in the **Workshop** menu ingame and click the `Open Sources` button.
3) In your mod's folder, there will be a file with the `.csproj` extension.
4) Open that `.csproj` file.  Give Visual Studio a few minutes to open the project.

(If you can't see file extensions, type `.hidden` in <#242228770855976960> to find out how to enable them.)

After you've followed the instructions above, you'll want to enable the Error List (`View > Error List`) and Solution Explorer (`View > Solution Explorer`).
Open code files from the Solution Explorer window instead of via `File > Open` or `Ctrl + O` to keep the project working as intended.

GuildTags.Name: whatisshoot10
GuildTags.Value:
For some reason, most ranged weapons in vanilla use `Item.shoot = 10;`
Why is that?  Well, `Item.useAmmo` isn't even considered unless `Item.shoot` is > 0, so the game uses an arbitrary value.  The actual projectile type is overwritten by the consumed ammo's `Item.shoot` value.

How To Play With The New Update

Vanilla 1.4 - Let Steam update the game, this will remove tModLoader and replace it with the new 1.4 update. (64bit users may have to delete the contents of the Steam folder)

Modded 1.3.5 (32x) - Download tModLoader on Steam, No need to edit the Terraria install once 1.4 goes live, this is how you will be accessing the modded client from now on.

Modded 1.3.5 (64x) - Follow the previous steps, then install 64bit over the tModLoader install, as you would have previously done with the Terraria install.

Modded 1.4 - This will take multiple months to release, as the developors need to rework the code to adjust for the new changes, and add code to manage the new content.

GuildTags.Name: calamity
GuildTags.Value:
Some Unbiased-Focused reasons why you may not want to use Calamity.
Bugs & Issues: In the past Calamity has contained game-breaking issues. Said issues have been falsely blamed on other mods by official calamity developers. They have often taken a while to have a patch. While this has improved in recent months, It's worth pointing out if you want to be sure to avoid issues.
Patreon: Calamity developers will implement fan suggestions if the fan provides money via Patreon & the suggestion is in reason. This is not inherently bad but some people may take issue with a lack of control over their own mod.
Lore: Calamity has a strong focus on lore, this is a massive contrast to the base-game & the quality of its implementation is up for discussion.
Self Insert: Calamity contains a Town NPC which is a direct representation of the creator of the mod. She sells alcohol & has 4th wall breaking dialog that contains adult humor.
Visual Design: The artstyle and visual design is notably different from a majority of the base-game content, to the extent that they are working on a texture pack to recreate the base-game with their new artstyle in mind.
Unoriginal Content:  Mechanics & items are blatantly taken from other media. Examples of games Calamity takes from are Subnautica, Hollow Knight, MGS:Revengence & Destiny. this content has been modified to fit Terraria.
Balance: Balance of enemies, equipment & weapons in Calamity are designed to scale up notably faster than the base-game, and a majority of mods that base their progression on the base-game. This can make a majority of Calamity's content overshadow other mods, as their weapons are stronger in comparison & bosses more difficult to beat when using non-Calamity content.
Performance: Calamity can be very intense on low end PC's, due to large ram usage & an abundance of dust & projectile usage, This can force most players to require more than 4GB of ram via 64bit TML.

GuildTags.Name: mpchunks
GuildTags.Value:
If you have missing chunks in Multiplayer, you might be experiencing a bug commonly seen with Magic Storage. The bug is related to too much data within a "chunk" of the game world. You need to move your storage units across multiple chunks so that the amount of data in each chunk is within the limit. We are working on solutions, but you can use the latest Modders Toolkit mod in the meantime to visualize the chunks and calculate the amount of data each chunk takes. Click the small button to open the tool, then the miscellaneous button to access the tool. Try to find a corner and spread your units between 4 separate chunks. Use storage connectors to span large distances. 

Picture of spread out Magic Storage: https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/436261997416546305/468336038155124737/unknown.png

Video of checking data limits in Modders Toolkit: https://gfycat.com/DownrightActualArthropods

GuildTags.Name: simpleinstall
GuildTags.Value:
If the manual install instructions from the `.install` tag were a bit too complicated to understand, try following what the below says:
1) Find where your vanilla game is installed.  By default on Windows computers, this is `C:/Program Files (x86)/Steam/steamapps/common/Terraria`.  If you changed the default install location, or you're on a non-Windows computer, then type `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960> to find out where it is.
2) In that `common` folder, create a new `tModLoader` folder.
3) Get a `.zip` folder from <#103130530886725632> or the releases page on the tModLoader GitHub.  Make sure you get the correct one!  For Windows users, it's the `tModLoader_Windows_v0.11.7.8.zip` folder.
4) Move the files from inside that `.zip` to into the `tModLoader` folder you created in step 2.
5) Run the `tModLoader` EXE file to play tModLoader.

If your game is still unable to boot up after doing this, then type `.hardreset` in <#242228770855976960>, follow its instructions and follow the steps above again.

GuildTags.Name: rarities
GuildTags.Value:
All rarites as of 9/27/2020 in vanilla terraria and at what point in the game you get them.
```
Gray - Lowest tier of items, including only junk fishing items and white + blue rarities with bad modifiers.
White - Common crafting materials, most furniture, building materials, and early tools + weapons + armor.
Blue - Weapons crafted from early ores, early drops/loot such as shackle or lucky horseshoe, banners, trophies, masks, fish, and pre-hm dyes.
Green - Mid pre-hm items most of which are looted, dropped, or purchased (not craftable) with a couple exceptions.
Orange - Late pre-hm items such as items made from hellstone, jungle items, and several hardmode items
Light Red - Early hm items, like items crafted from hm ores, drops from early hm enemies, very rare drops, and some late pre-hm items.
Pink - Mid hm items (pre plantera) such as flamethrower, optic staff, and hallowed armor. Also includes more expensive hm npc items, rarer hm drops, and certain pre-hm vanity.
Light Purple - smaller tier of the rarest pre-plantera items such as the death sickle/coin gun, and some higher tier tinkerer's workshop combinations
Lime - Items obtained around plantera/golem, and the hm underground jungle. Also contains powerful tinkerer's workshop combinations such as cellphone/frostspark boots.
Yellow - Items aquired from the post-plantera dungeon, drops from late-game events, duke fishron drops, all mounts, and a few other items.
Cyan - Early lunar event items such as lunar fragments and monoliths, some moon lord drops, and developer items.
Red - Items crafted at the ancient manipulator with lunar fragments and/or luminite, and some moon lord drops.
Purple - Cyan and Red items that have high tier modifiers. No vanilla item (currently) has this tier.
Expert - Expert mode-exclusive items (except developer items) and treasure bags.
Fiery Red - (1.4) Master mode-exclusive items.
Quest - Quest items that are given to quest-giving npcs.
```

GuildTags.Name: unmodifiedexe

If you get an error saying you need an unmodified exe, delete both the vanilla and tModLoader folders and reinstall from STEAM.
Both folders can be found in:
Windows: `C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Terraria`
Mac: `Library/Application Support/Steam/steamapps/common/Terraria/Terraria.app/Contents/MacOS`
Linux: `~/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/Terraria or ~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/Terraria`
For more info, type `.hardreset` into <#242228770855976960>.

Note: This will not touch your saves, those are not located in the STEAM directory.

If you're getting an error that `tModLoader.FNA.exe` doesn't exist, follow these instructions:
1) Find your install folder.  If you don't know where this is, type `.findinstall` in <#242228770855976960> to find out.

3) Go into the Mod Sources menu ingame and let it redownload the ModCompile.

GuildTags.Name: linuxmodbrowser
GuildTags.Value:
Unable to download mods on Linux? Try these steps below -

***Step 1 -*** Install the latest version of Mono <https://www.mono-project.com/download/stable/#download-lin>.
***Step 2 -*** Sync your certificates using these commands in the terminal -
***Ubuntu / Debian / Arch:*** `sudo cert-sync /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt`
***Fedora / CentOS:*** `etc sudo cert-sync /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt`

***Note -*** Step 2 is only necessary if you want to download large mods. Mono by itself seems to work when downloading smaller mods.

GuildTags.Name: criticism
GuildTags.Value:
**[Insert Comment About Criticism Here]**
Criticism is a sticky subject, and there is no finite dogma to define it. However, we can assume based on norms how criticism should and should not be.

Here are simple dos and don'ts:
**DO:**
- Address both the problem and a __positive__ way to improve said issue. 
- Acknowledge progress and evolution of all spriters.
- Be accepting of all valid criticism, whether you asked for it or not.
- Know what you're talking about before giving accurate feedback.

**DO NOT:**
- Spritebash, or give extremely negative and sometimes derogatory feedback towards sprites.
- Point out the negatives and offering no way to fix them.
- Joke-feedbacking is fine, however know the limits between joking and bashing.
- Bash previous works that are not representative of the spriter's current skill.

*Alternatively, there are 2 avenues to get people to make sprites for you:
- <#832559053515259944>: For small or singular jobs, you can use the requests channel to request a sprite to be made.

GuildTags.Name: gog142
GuildTags.Value:
If you are getting the `GOG installs must have the unmodified Terraria executable to function.` error, it's probably because you updated Terraria to 1.4.2 and tML hasn't updated to support 1.4.2 installations yet, so until it updates, downgrade your Terraria to 1.4.1.2: 

If you are using GoG Galaxy, to downgrade:
> Click on the game in the side bar, should take you to a page that says "Play" in green and next to that is a "More" drop down menu
> In the "More" menu, go to "Settings"
> In "Settings" there should be a list of "Override Features" including Auto-Updates
> Uncheck the "Automatically update to newest version" box, that should make a list pop up of which version you want to revert to.
 And downgrade to `1.4.1.2`

GuildTags.Name: directionto
GuildTags.Value:
Do you want to make something like an NPC or projectile move towards something else? Use DirectionTo(), a fun method you can plug into projectiles and NPCs and even players! just do 
```cs
something.velocity = something.DirectionTo(some Vector2 you want it to go towards);
```
 and multiply it by any number you want, the bigger, the faster! It's that easy!

here's a fun example:
```cs
projectile.velocity = projectile.DirectionTo(Main.MouseWorld) * 7f;
//it will go towards the mouse
```
make sure to only run it once, or you'll end up in a homing thing, unless that's what you want!

GuildTags.Name: mixels
GuildTags.Value: Your sprite has mixels. No, not that one cartoon. Mixels. Mixels are mixed sizes of pixels, likely caused by you editing a sprite originally in 2x2, bad exporting, or using different pixel size brushes for whatever reason. Terraria sprites use pixels that are in 2x2, and things look very strange if the pixels are mixed sizes. To avoid mixels or to remove them, edit/make sprites without them originally being in 2x2 but then export in 2x2. If the export is bad, try using more popular spriting softwares like Piskel, Aseprite, paint.net, etc.

GuildTags.Name: vsdowngrade
GuildTags.Value:
If you wish to downgrade VS, here are the steps:
1. Go to `Tools -> Import and Export settings...`, create a full backup of your settings (including the 'sensitive' stuff, because you can delete the backup afterwards)
2. Open the VS installer, and create a backup of your VS installation configuration.
3. Delete your VS installation and close VS installer.
4. Go to <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2019/history#release-dates-and-build-numbers>.
5. Find the right version (if you want to fix EaC, you want 16.8.3). Download the installer by clicking on either Enterprise or Professional. It doesn't matter what they say, you'll still be able to install Community.
6. When you get to the list of features you want to install, click on the 'X'.
7. Go to the Available tab, you'll see available Community, Enterprise and Professional VS installs with the version you chose to downgrade to. Choose install on one of them, importing a setup configuration file you exported previously. Install, preferably to the same folder as previously.
8. After ten hours of waiting for VS to install, launch it and import your VS settings through the same dialog you exported them with.

[1.1]: Do not negate criticism. 
[1.2]: Be constructive when giving criticism.

GuildTags.Name: dotnet6switch
GuildTags.Value:
**Why am I getting multiple warnings and errors referencing .NET 6.0?**
Recently, the 1.4 alpha has moved to using .NET 6.0, meaning that for some users, VS 2019 will not be able to support modding. 
The .NET 6.0 SDK can be found at: https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/6.0

In order to allow VS 2019 to use 6.0, you'll need to target that specific version in your csproj by editing the line ``<TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>``. Afterwards, restart VS. (This option will only work for some users, as results seem to vary on whether everything resolves)

If that does not work, the second option would be transferring over to VS 2022, the latest iteration of VS that supports .NET 6.0. Your mod's csproj should automatically transfer over after installation, so no need to worry about anything complex.

GuildTags.Value:
Calamity Mod alters the way that the player obtains the early-Hardmode ores.
Cobalt/Palladium spawns after defeating the Wall of Flesh.
Mythril/Orichalcum spawns after defeating 1 mech boss.
Adamantite/Titanium spawns after defeating 2 mech bosses.
Hallowed Ore spawns in the *Underground Hallow* after defeating all 3 mech bosses.
**If you don't want this to happen, disable the "Early Hardmode Progression Changes" config**
Each ore tier only spawns in the world *once*.  After defeating all 3 mech bosses, subsequent defeats cause them to drop Hallowed Bars like usual.

GuildTags.Name: consoletml
GuildTags.Value:
**Will There Be A tML for Console / Mobile?**
Short answer: no.
Long answer: still no.
In general, a mobile or console release of tML would take a drastically long time to code, get approved, and released. Consoles and mobile devices utilize different languages, meaning tML would have to be rewritten entirely to fit those specifications. Alongside that, architecture of mobile devices in particular would not be capable of handling a modding platform.

As far as legality, a modding platform on a console or mobile device can easily serve as another backdoor for malicious programs, viruses, or piracy to seep its way into platforms. Offering backdoors like this would easily not only violate terms and conditions with multiple companies, but also serve as the basis for potential legal trouble.

GuildTags.Name: dirmove
GuildTags.Value:
If you're getting errors related to `Directory.Move`, read the following instructions:
1) Cut the `Beta` folder in `Documents/My Games/Terraria/ModLoader`
2) Paste that `Beta` folder to `Documents/My Games/Terraria`
3) Rename the folder to `tModLoader`
4) In that new `tModLoader` folder, rename all folders that have spaces in their names (e.g. `Mod Sources`, `Mod Configs`, `Mod Reader`) to have no spaces (e.g. `ModSources`, `ModConfigs`, `ModReader`)
5) Profit

If you're getting an error that the `Beta` folder is currently being used, try the following instead:
1) Create a `tModLoader` folder in `Documents/My Games/Terraria`
2) Cut the ***contents*** of the `Beta` folder
3) Paste them into the `tModLoader` folder created in step 1
4) In that new `tModLoader` folder, rename all folders that have spaces in their names (e.g. `Mod Sources`, `Mod Configs`, `Mod Reader`) to have no spaces (e.g. `ModSources`, `ModConfigs`, `ModReader`)
5) Profit

missingcontentfolder
GuildTags.Value:
The content folder referred to in the error is not your mod's Content folder.
This error typically stems from having the wrong version of Steamworks.NET installed for your platform (the UNIX version on Windows, and vice versa).

To fix it, verify your game files.
On Linux and Mac, go to your tModLoader installation directory, copy the PlatformVariantLibs/UNIX.Steamworks.NET.dll file to Libraries/Steamworks.NET/20.1.0.0/, delete the Steamworks.NET.dll file in that folder, and rename the UNIX.Steamworks.NET.dll file in that same folder to Steamworks.NET.dll.
Finally, delete any empty shells on the Steam Workshop, the Workshop.json file inside your ModSources directory, and the Workshop directory in your tModLoader data files (the place where Mods, ModSources, etc.) is located.
You should be able to upload your mod. If this still does not work, try changing the workshop ID manually (<https://discord.com/channels/103110554649894912/534215632795729922/889244728846065675>).

GuildTags.Name: modernbits
GuildTags.Value:
**For players (layman's explanation):**
tModLoader 1.4 is natively 64bit, you don't need any external software (such as forks) to make it 64bit.

**For advanced users (modders, developers, etc.):**
tModLoader 1.4 is compiled to the *Any CPU* CPU target, meaning it works on both 32bit and 64bit PCs. __However__, the native `steamapi` library shipped with tML is 64bit-only, so there is a hardcoded check in tML that throws an exception for 32bit users (for now).

GuildTags.Name: tellmehow
GuildTags.Value:
Users are not going to spoon-feed you answers, nor will they solve life's problems in your place. So, when receiving help, you may encounter these general solutions:
```cs
NPC.HealEffect(parameters);
if(condition)
Player.XXX = someValue;
```
If you are seeing any of these, **you are not being told to copy this letter for letter**. That will not work when you try to compile it, and you will be very sad.
Instead, think critically about what you should change...
> `parameters` doesn't exist, but you know `HealEffect` wants an `int`, so you use `NPC.HealEffect(10)`
> `condition` doesn't exist, but you know `if` checks true and false statements, so you use `if(X > Y)`
> `Player` doesn't have a definition for `XXX`, but it does have a definition for `statLifeMax2`

Instructions on how to install and use **TML.Patcher**, a third-party software for decompiling mods:
1) Open `Command Prompt`
2) Run `dotnet tool install -g Tomat.TML.Patcher` to install the tool
3) Run `tmlpatcher extract "Path/To/The/Mod.tmod"` to extract the mod file at `Path/To/The/Mod.tmod`
The extracted mod files will be located within the folder that you ran the command in step 3) at.

GuildTags.Name: movespeed
GuildTags.Value:
If you want to modify the player's ground movement, you should use the `PostUpdateRunSpeeds` hook in `ModPlayer` for modifying these variables:
- `Player.maxRunSpeed`:  the player's maximum X-velocity
- `Player.accRunSpeed`:  the player's maximum X-velocity when using a grounded mount or accessories like the Hermes Boots
- `Player.runAcceleration`:  how quickly the player will reach `maxRunSpeed`/`accRunSpeed`

On the other hand, the following variable is read BEFORE `PostUpdateRunSpeeds`.  When modifying this variable, you should use any hooks at or before `PostUpdateMiscEffects` hook in `ModPlayer` instead, which includes `UpdateAccessory` and `UpdateEquip` in ModItem:
- `Player.moveSpeed`:  this variable is used as a *strength modifier* for `runAcceleration` and `maxRunSpeed`.  treat this variable like a "global movement modifier" of sorts

GuildTags.Name: starlight
GuildTags.Value:
## Having problems with Starlight River?
Hey there! If you're having issues accessing Starlight River, here are a couple common problems and solutions:
### "Wrong version?" aka "v2023.6.4.0 when on 2022.x.x.x": You're on the 1.4.3 version of the game when SLR was made for the preview version.
- FOR STEAM: Library => right click tML => "Properties" => "Betas" => select "1.4.4-preview" from the dropdown and wait for the update.
- FOR NON-STEAM: You can find the latest preview version on the tModLoader Github page.
### "My Character's been corrupted!"
- This should've been fixed by now (as of 6/5/2023), but if it's not, do not place any cooked food items into your inventory until you update, as this was a save/load issue
### "[some other issue relating to the mod]"
- Further inquiries can be directed to the Starlight River official discord at https://discord.gg/starlightriver

GuildTags.Name: complexaccessory
GuildTags.Value:
Sometimes it isn't possible to create an effect for an accessory without supplementing it with other stuff. A common pattern to follow is using a bool field/property on a class that inherits `ModPlayer`. Here's a quick rundown of how to set this pattern up:
- Your accessory item uses its `UpdateAccessory` hook to set our bool field, `SomeAccessoryBool`, on a class inheriting `ModPlayer`, `SomeAccessoryPlayer`: `player.GetModPlayer<SomeAccessoryPlayer>().SomeAccessoryBool = true`
- Then, `SomeAccessoryPlayer` uses its `ResetEffects` hook to set `SomeAccessoryBool` back to false. This makes it so we don't need to add any extra logic for handling unequiping our accessory
- Finally, we can implement any effect we want using any hooks on `SomeAccessoryPlayer`

Here's an example of this pattern in action:
Accessory: <https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/stable/ExampleMod/Content/Items/Accessories/ExampleImmunityAccessory.cs>
Player: <https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/blob/stable/ExampleMod/Common/Players/ExampleImmunityPlayer.cs>

GuildTags.Name: chatgpt
GuildTags.Value:
ChatGPT and other generative language-models aren't suited for developing generally, and especially developing mods with tModLoader. There are a few reasons for this:
- The current models of ChatGPT are trained on data from years ago, meaning it has no concept of even 1.4 tModLoader. With tModLoader being updated every month, this won't produce reliably up to date code
- ChatGPT is often confidently wrong, claiming one thing while the code does another or missing potential bugs. This might be obvious to more experienced programmers, but it can trip newer modders up
- ChatGPT doesn't know anything, all it knows is placing one word in front of another based on the ongoing conversation. It doesn't know the meaning of words and it can't explain its thought process behind the code it's created

ChatGPT is a great tool for modding, it can help brainstorm or come up with names for things. It can even do some menial text parsing, if you're patient enough. However, it isn't suited for writing code, so please don't use it for that

GuildTags.Name: msbwarn
GuildTags.Value:
You can remove the `MSB3270` warning very easily, just edit your `ModName.csproj` file, and add 
```xml
<ResolveAssemblyWarnOrErrorOnTargetArchitectureMismatch>None</ResolveAssemblyWarnOrErrorOnTargetArchitectureMismatch>```
to the `PropertyGroup` node. Note: Some IDEs require you to unload the `.csproj` file before making edits to it, if you don't see an "Edit" button, you likely have to do that first

# Wondering Why Mods Aren't Updated?
Hey! If you're reading this, you've probably asked quite a couple times why your mods aren't updated or why your mods are crashing! The reason is likely that tModLoader updated to a newer version, and thus, those mods need time to port to the new update. 

There is no fix for this besides:
- going to a previous version of tML, which can be accessed via the Github Releases page.
- waiting patiently like a normal human being until it's fixed.

Please refrain from asking further about the topic, and, in the event someone else asks: pass it on!

The more you tell people, the less people ask! Post this tag 500+ times if you have to so people get the message!

-mgmt

GuildTags.Name: badrp
GuildTags.Value:
You have a resource pack enabled that is not compatible with tModLoader. Follow this section of the FAQ to disable the resource packs from your `config.json` so you can open the game again <https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Basic-tModLoader-Usage-FAQ#disable-all-resource-packs>

Explanation: tModLoader is more strict about what files are in mods and in resource packs. The resource pack has two files with the same name, but with different file extensions. For Example: `Item_1.png` and `Item_1.xnb` or `Music_1.wav` and `Music_1.mp3`. Vanilla just ignores one of the duplicates, but tModLoader detects both and raises an error. To fix it, either remove one of the duplicate files or place one of the duplicate files in a non-standard folder so it won't be read by the resource pack system. If you are not the author of the resource pack, report it to the author so they can update the resource pack.

GuildTags.Name: assertionfailed
GuildTags.Value:
If you getting an error such as `Assertion failed: !FAILED(hr) && "Failed to find supported audio format!"` or `Assertion failed: !FAILED(hr) && "Failed to activate audio client!"` in your `Natives.log`, **there is an issue your with audio device** (your speakers/headphones/etc.).
Things to try:
* Terraria and tModLoader really don't like it if you have no audio output. If you don't have one connected, try connecting one.
* If you have an audio output but you are getting the error, try switching to a different audio device (different speakers, headphones, etc.)
* Make sure your audio output rate is less than or equal to 48000 Hz.
* If you are using Voicemeeter, you need to configure your A1-A5 devices.
* If you have Sony INZONE headphones, try setting the output device as "Chat" instead of "Game".
* Try the IAudioClient workaround in the tModLoader FAQ.
Audio Issues section of the FAQ <https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Basic-tModLoader-Usage-FAQ#audio-issues>

##The easiest way to post your logs is as follows:
> In Steam right click on tModLoader in the library, then hover over Manage and click on Browse local files. In the folder that appears find tModLoader-Logs and open that folder. Inside that folder are the logs files.

##Alternatively, your logs can be found in these locations:
> **Windows**:
> ``C:/Users/[YOUR_USERNAME]/MyGames/Terraria/tModLoader/Logs``
> **Mac**:
> ``~/Library/Application support/Terraria/Logs``
> **Linux**:
> ``~/.local/share/Steam/steamapps/common/tModLoader/Logs`` or ``~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/tModLoader/Logs``

You will want to upload the **Client.Log file**, as well as the **Server.Log file** ***If you were in multiplayer and were the host***

Note that these files may appear as just **Client** or **Server** if you have file extensions turned off!

GuildTags.Name: binarysearch
GuildTags.Value:
Binary Search is a debugging technique used to find the mod or mods that are causing the issues you are experiencing. The method is simple: to find the conflicting mods, split your mods folder into 2 groups. Remove one group, and test in-game. Keep the group that has the problem, and repeat until no more mods can be removed without the issue disappearing. The remaining mod, or a conflict of multiple remaining mods, will be pinpointed as the cause of your issue.
https://i.imgur.com/qNmAt76.gif

Practice exercises, apply what you learn to small scale problems <https://www.codewars.com/>

This is not an exhaustive list - if nothing here works out for you then feel free to use some of the learning resources from the documentation page listed above, or go searching for your own

GuildTags.Name: learnil
GuildTags.Value:
Sometimes certain effects aren't possible with tMod hooks or detours, this is where IL edits come in. IL is the language that C# compiles to, we aren't able to edit the C# code but we are able to edit the IL instructions. The language itself is very simple, it is easy enough to learn.

Here are some resources for learning IL itself:
IL wiki page, a useful primer if you've never seen IL before <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Intermediate_Language#Computational_model>
OpCodes docs, a list of every OpCode and a short explanation of what they mean <https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.reflection.emit.opcodes?view=net-8.0>
sharplab, a helpful tool for seeing what IL instructions a snippet of C# will compile to <https://sharplab.io/>
ILSpy, a .net decompiler that allows you to see IL instructions alongside the C# that creates them <https://github.com/icsharpcode/ILSpy>

Here are some resources for learning to patch existing IL instructions with MonoMod:
MonoMod API reference, note you will mostly be looking at the `ILCursor` class <https://monomod.dev/api/MonoMod.html>
IL Editing guide, ignore the section above this about manually patching the game, this explains a few different approaches to the same patch <https://github.com/tModLoader/tModLoader/wiki/Expert-IL-Editing#patch-code>
Examples in terraria mods in the wild, note that these may not follow best practices <https://github.com/search?q=path%3A*.cs+monomodhooks.modify&type=code>

GuildTags.Name: performance
GuildTags.Value:
# There is no magic performance fix we can give you.

## But I have []GB of RAM!!
Having a large amount of memory will not magically make the game run faster, much like having a bigger trunk wont magically make your car drive faster. TModLoader will use as much memory as it needs from your system already, you cannot and would have no benefit to 'using more RAM', much like filling your trunk with random junk wont make your car go faster.

## But the CPU/GPU usage is only []%!!
Much like memory, the game will use as much processing power as it needs. Ultimately the majority of the game is single threaded with a few exceptions, and as such is usually limited by single core clock speed.

## But why is it not multithreaded?!?!
Multithreading isn't a universal cure-all nor is it simple to handle. The game relies on consistent execution order to calculate things, and often the cost of *lock contention*, or threads waiting on others for sensitive memory, can exceed the cost of simply running everything sequentially on one thread. A full re-write of the game designed with thread safety in mind would be needed, and the gains would likely be less than expected.

## But I have a GTX5090 giga super mega card!!
While having a powerful graphics card can help a little, Terraria is still largely considered a CPU bound game. Additionally, the advancements in newer cards are more focused on features such as 3D raytracing cores and tensor cores for processing things like global illumination and frame generation AI models, which wont help.

# So what can I even do?!?!
The only guaranteed way to improve your performance is to **use less mods**, ultimately **no hardware will make up for poorly made mods!** Most mods are made by hobbyists and novices with limited time/knowledge.
